body:
After some investigation (where it turns out it's actually quite hard to force gpr output logs to NUnit console), it seems the crash is not within grpc_shutdown.

The log from test that creates a server and immediately shuts it down:
The main problem seems to be "assertion failed: !info->cb"

I0223 20:08:15.715000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\resolve_address_windows.c:115: logspam: getaddrinfo(localhost, 0) resolved 2 addrs in 16ms:
I0223 20:08:15.715000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\resolve_address_windows.c:121: logspam:   [0] [::1]:0
I0223 20:08:15.715000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\resolve_address_windows.c:121: logspam:   [1] 127.0.0.1:0
D0223 20:08:15.715000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\socket_windows.c:49: grpc_winsocket_create
D0223 20:08:15.715000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\socket_windows.c:49: grpc_winsocket_create
D0223 20:08:15.715000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:196: grpc_socket_notify_on_read
D0223 20:08:15.715000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:182: socket_notify_on_iocp - queued
D0223 20:08:15.715000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:196: grpc_socket_notify_on_read
D0223 20:08:15.715000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:182: socket_notify_on_iocp - queued
D0223 20:08:15.730000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\socket_windows.c:64: grpc_winsocket_shutdown
D0223 20:08:15.730000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\socket_windows.c:64: grpc_winsocket_shutdown
D0223 20:08:15.730000000  7564 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\tcp_server_windows.c:239: on_accept: shutting down
D0223 20:08:15.730000000  7564 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:196: grpc_socket_notify_on_read
E0223 20:08:15.730000000  7564 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:173: assertion failed: !info->cb
D0223 20:08:15.730000000 10192 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:92: do_iocp_work - got read packet
D0223 20:08:15.730000000 10192 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:100: bytes: 0, flags: 0 - op failed
E0223 20:08:15.730000000 10192 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\tcp_server_windows.c:231: on_accept error: The I/O operation has been aborted because of either a thread exit or an application request.

D0223 20:08:15.730000000 10192 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:196: grpc_socket_notify_on_read
D0223 20:08:15.730000000 10192 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:182: socket_notify_on_iocp - queued
D0223 20:08:15.730000000 10192 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\tcp_server_windows.c:239: on_accept: shutting down
D0223 20:08:15.730000000 10192 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:196: grpc_socket_notify_on_read
E0223 20:08:15.730000000 10192 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:173: assertion failed: !info->cb
D0223 20:08:15.730000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\socket_windows.c:70: grpc_winsocket_orphan
D0223 20:08:15.730000000  8228 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\socket_windows.c:70: grpc_winsocket_orphan

Callstack:
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!socket_notify_on_iocp(grpc_winsocket \* socket, void (void *, int) \* cb, void \* opaque, grpc_winsocket_callback_info \* info) Line 173    C
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!grpc_socket_notify_on_read(grpc_winsocket \* socket, void (void *, int) \* cb, void \* opaque) Line 197    C
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!start_accept(server_port \* port) Line 206   C
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!on_accept(void \* arg, int success) Line 249 C
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!background_callback_executor(void \* ignored) Line 72    C
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!thread_body(void \* v) Line 54   C

I can reproduce the exact same assertion with a minimal program containing just a server with a single service and a single client executing one rpc call.

Changing my test code to only create the server with a single service and immediately shutdown again, reproducibly results in crash in gpr_mu_lock(mu) when accessing mu->cs because mu is 0.
Callstack:

>   model_server.exe!gpr_mu_lock(gpr_mu \* mu) Line 55   C
>     model_server.exe!do_iocp_work(...) Line 106 C
>     model_server.exe!iocp_loop(void \* p) Line 121   C
>     model_server.exe!thread_body(void \* v) Line 56  C

sync_win32.c:

> void gpr_mu_lock(gpr_mu *mu) {
>   EnterCriticalSection(&mu->cs); // <= Crashes here because mu is 0.
>   GPR_ASSERT(!mu->locked);
>   mu->locked = 1;
> }

I tried to find out what's causing it but did not make much progress. Feel free to ping me if I can be of help (e.g. testing...).
Can you please send me the entire code that reproduces the issue. You can create a PR against my fork of the main repo https://github.com/jtattermusch/grpc.

Seems I can't see it. Can you please send a link?

On Mon, Mar 9, 2015 at 2:38 PM, codeandroid notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I did (hopefully... as I'm still new to the PR workflow).
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/546#issuecomment-77948676.

Sorry, I'm new to the PR workflow so I may have made an error.

Here's a link to the commit with the example: https://github.com/codeandroid/grpc/commit/39927f522599e33f7c1f94aeb55fde77302f22dd

What's the workflow, should I create project files, too? I looked into generate_projects.sh and the mako templates. I can probably get it done that way, though locally I simply used premake5 to generate them.

I ran the C# Grpc.IntegrationTesting.Server and Client which exhibits similar behavior during shutdown:

> \src\core\support\sync_win32.c:55: assertion failed: !mu->locked

So you are using C++ code and you are able to compile (we don't support yet actually)? Could you please provide a snapshot of your whole example including the project files - everything that's needed to actually run the test code. We could use that example to debug the issue.

I will add the C++ projects, yes.

Still, the C# code exhibits the same crash and it does not use the C++ layer.
That debugbreak is here because I had no idea how to provoke that codepath - and I wanted to test it. None of my tests were able to. Just remove that line - it might just work :-)

In fact, there's 4 other debugbreaks I've left in the Windows port. All of them are codepaths I couldn't test, and I don't like not having good code coverage at least during my development. But each of these codepaths should in fact gracefully recover. Should. As I couldn't test, I can't be 100% sure.

But feel free to remove all of them. Maybe I should put them in a macro or something if people are actually using that Windows port :-)

So, the __debugbreak() problem is unrelated to the issue. The actual problem is what I have already described:
E4/21/2015 2:20:06 PM 108558992 c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\iocp_windows.c:188: assertion failed: !info->cb

```
grpc_csharp_ext.dll!socket_notify_on_iocp(grpc_winsocket * socket, void (void *, int) * cb, void * opaque, grpc_winsocket_callback_info * info) Line 188    C
grpc_csharp_ext.dll!grpc_socket_notify_on_read(grpc_winsocket * socket, void (void *, int) * cb, void * opaque) Line 212    C
grpc_csharp_ext.dll!start_accept(server_port * port) Line 214   C
```

>   grpc_csharp_ext.dll!on_accept(void \* arg, int success) Line 260 C
>     grpc_csharp_ext.dll!grpc_maybe_call_delayed_callbacks(gpr_mu \* drop_mu, int success) Line 209   C
>     grpc_csharp_ext.dll!grpc_pollset_work(grpc_pollset \* pollset, gpr_timespec deadline) Line 66    C
>     grpc_csharp_ext.dll!grpc_completion_queue_next(grpc_completion_queue \* cc, gpr_timespec deadline) Line 311  C
>     grpc_csharp_ext.dll!grpcsharp_completion_queue_next_with_callback(grpc_completion_queue \* cq) Line 310  C

How to reproduce: basically run any C# test (I ran MathClientServerTest.Div1).

It looks like this can be prevented by adding 
if (success) for start_accept(sp)  in tcp_server_windows.c:259

After doing that, you will run into several other issues:

a) either things work fine but iocp_windows.c: do_iocp_work will never terminate (it gets a kick and then goes to sleep again because of handling of orphan sockets).

b) or you get access violation exception at 
success = port->AcceptEx(port->socket->socket, ...  because port->socket = 0xfeeefeee (which most likely means it has been freed before).
stacktrace:
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!start_accept(server_port \* port) Line 201   C
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!on_accept(void \* arg, int success) Line 260 C
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!do_iocp_work(...) Line 122  C
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!iocp_loop(void \* p) Line 129    C
    grpc_csharp_ext.dll!thread_body(void \* v) Line 72   C

c) you get and error: c:\users\jtattermusch\github\grpc\src\core\iomgr\tcp_server_windows.c:238: on_accept error: An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket.  (which might be connected to the fact that the socket has been freed before).
Added bug for the use-after-free problem separately https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/1346
